infodynamics.measures.continuous

Class ActiveInfoStorageCalculatorViaMutualInfo

  • java.lang.Object
    • infodynamics.measures.continuous.ActiveInfoStorageCalculatorViaMutualInfo
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ActiveInfoStorageCalculator, InfoMeasureCalculatorContinuous, EmpiricalNullDistributionComputer
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    ActiveInfoStorageCalculatorGaussian, ActiveInfoStorageCalculatorKernel, ActiveInfoStorageCalculatorKraskov, ActiveInfoStorageCalculatorMultiVariateViaMutualInfo

    public class ActiveInfoStorageCalculatorViaMutualInfo
extends java.lang.Object
implements ActiveInfoStorageCalculator
    An Active Information Storage (AIS) calculator (implementing ActiveInfoStorageCalculator) which is affected using a given Mutual Information (MI) calculator (implementing MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate) to make the calculations.

    Usage is as per the paradigm outlined for ActiveInfoStorageCalculator, except that in the constructor(s) for this class the implementation for a MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate must be supplied. Further properties may be set on this class via setProperty(String, String) (including auto-embedding parameters) as described in the javadocs for that method.

    This class may be used directly, however users are advised that several child classes are available which already plug-in the various MI estimators to provide AIS calculators (taking specific caution associated with each type of estimator):

    • ActiveInfoStorageCalculatorGaussian
    • ActiveInfoStorageCalculatorKernel
    • ActiveInfoStorageCalculatorKraskov

    References:

    • J.T. Lizier, M. Prokopenko and A.Y. Zomaya, "Local measures of information storage in complex distributed computation", Information Sciences, vol. 208, pp. 39-54, 2012.
    Author:
    Joseph Lizier (email, www)
    See Also:
    ActiveInfoStorageCalculator

        protected int k
        Length of past history to consider (embedding length)

      • tau

        protected int tau
        Embedding delay to use between elements of the embeding vector. We're hard-coding a delay of 1 between the history vector and the next observation however.

        Whether debug mode is on

      • setProperty

        public void setProperty(java.lang.String propertyName,
               java.lang.String propertyValue)
                 throws java.lang.Exception
        Set properties for the underlying calculator implementation. New property values are not guaranteed to take effect until the next call to an initialise method.

        Allowable property names include:

        • Those defined for the ActiveInfoStorageCalculator interface (i.e. ActiveInfoStorageCalculator.K_PROP_NAME or ActiveInfoStorageCalculator.TAU_PROP_NAME)
        • PROP_AUTO_EMBED_METHOD -- method by which the calculator automatically determines the embedding history length (ActiveInfoStorageCalculator.K_PROP_NAME) and embedding delay (ActiveInfoStorageCalculator.TAU_PROP_NAME). Default is AUTO_EMBED_METHOD_NONE meaning values are set manually; other accepted values include: AUTO_EMBED_METHOD_RAGWITZ for use of the Ragwitz criteria and AUTO_EMBED_METHOD_MAX_CORR_AIS for using the maz bias-corrected AIS criteria (both searching up to PROP_K_SEARCH_MAX and PROP_TAU_SEARCH_MAX, as outlined by Garland et al. in the references list above). Use of any value other than AUTO_EMBED_METHOD_NONE will lead to any previous settings for k and tau (via e.g. initialise(int, int) or auto-embedding during previous calculations) will be overwritten after observations are supplied.
        • PROP_K_SEARCH_MAX -- maximum embedded history length to search up to if automatically determining the embedding parameters (as set by PROP_AUTO_EMBED_METHOD); default is 1
        • PROP_TAU_SEARCH_MAX -- maximum embedded history length to search up to if automatically determining the embedding parameters (as set by PROP_AUTO_EMBED_METHOD); default is 1
        • PROP_RAGWITZ_NUM_NNS -- number of nearest neighbours to use in the auto-embedding if the property PROP_AUTO_EMBED_METHOD has been set to AUTO_EMBED_METHOD_RAGWITZ. Defaults to the property value set for MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateKraskov.PROP_K
        • Any properties defined for the underlying InfoMeasureCalculatorContinuous.setProperty(String, String) implementation, however the user is not allowed to set the property MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate.PROP_TIME_DIFF here. This would set a time difference from the history vector to the next step, which we currently do not allow. (If we change our mind one day and allow it, we could implement it simply by letting the time diff property be set here).

        Note that implementing classes may defined additional properties.

        Specified by:
        setProperty in interface ActiveInfoStorageCalculator
        Specified by:
        setProperty in interface InfoMeasureCalculatorContinuous
        Parameters:
        propertyName - name of the property
        propertyValue - value of the property
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - for invalid property values

      • addObservations

        public void addObservations(double[] observations,
                   boolean[] valid)
                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from interface: ActiveInfoStorageCalculator
        Add more time-series for the computation of the PDF, subject to the validity of each sample in that series. The array observations must not be over-written by the user until after finaliseAddObservations() has been called.
        Specified by:
        addObservations in interface ActiveInfoStorageCalculator
        Parameters:
        observations - time-series array of (univariate) samples, where the array index is time.
        valid - a time series (with indices the same as observations) indicating whether the entry in observations at that index is valid; we only take vectors as samples to add to the observation set where all points in the time series (even between points in the embedded k-vector with embedding delays) are valid.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • preFinaliseAddObservations

        protected void preFinaliseAddObservations()
                                   throws java.lang.Exception
        Hook in case child implementations need to perform any processing on the observation time series prior to their being processed and supplied to the underlying MI calculator. Primarily this is to allow the child implementation to automatically determine embedding parameters if desired, and a default implementation is provided for this for the main two auto-embedding methods. Child implementations do not need to override this default empty implementation if no new functionality is required.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeAdditionalBiasToRemove

        protected double computeAdditionalBiasToRemove()
                                        throws java.lang.Exception
        Internal method to compute any additional bias correction in the underlying calculator during auto-embedding in preFinaliseAddObservations() if required.
        Returns:
        additional bias correction to remove (will be zero if assumed to be already bias corrected).
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • prepareMICalculator

        protected void prepareMICalculator(MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate miCalc_in_use,
                       int k_in_use,
                       int tau_in_use)
                            throws java.lang.Exception
        Prepare the given pre-instantiated (and properties supplied) Mutual information calculator with this data set, using the embedding parameters supplied. This may be used in the final calculation, or by the auto-embedding procedures, hence the use of method arguments rather than using the member variables directly.
        Parameters:
        miCalc_in_use - MI calculator to supply
        k_in_use - k embedding dimension to use
        tau_in_use - tau embedding delay to use
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeStartAndEndTimePairs

        public java.util.Vector<int[]> computeStartAndEndTimePairs(boolean[] valid)
        Compute a vector of start and end pairs of time points, between which we have valid series of observations.

        This method is made public so it can be used if one wants to compute the number of observations prior to making a call to setObservations(double[], boolean[]).

        Functions as per computeStartAndEndTimePairs(int, int, boolean[]) with k and tau set to the property values of this calculator.

        Parameters:
        valid - a time series (with indices the same as observations) indicating whether the entry in observations at that index is valid; we only take vectors as samples to add to the observation set where all points in the time series (even between points in the embedded k-vector with embedding delays) are valid.
        Returns:
        a vector for start and end time pairs of valid series of observations (as defined by valid).

      • computeStartAndEndTimePairs

        public java.util.Vector<int[]> computeStartAndEndTimePairs(int k_in_use,
                                                  int tau_in_use,
                                                  boolean[] valid)
        Compute a vector of start and end pairs of time points, between which we have valid series of observations.

        This method is made public so it can be used if one wants to compute the number of observations prior to making a call to setObservations(double[], boolean[]).

        Parameters:
        k_in_use - the k embedding dimension parameter to use here
        tau_in_use - the tau embedding delay parameter to use here
        valid - a time series (with indices the same as observations) indicating whether the entry in observations at that index is valid; we only take vectors as samples to add to the observation set where all points in the time series (even between points in the embedded k-vector with embedding delays) are valid.
        Returns:
        a vector for start and end time pairs of valid series of observations (as defined by valid).

      • computeLocalOfPreviousObservations

        public double[] computeLocalOfPreviousObservations()
                                            throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from interface: ActiveInfoStorageCalculator
        Compute the local AIS values for each of the previously-supplied samples.

        PDFs are computed using all of the previously supplied observations.

        If the samples were supplied via a single call such as ActiveInfoStorageCalculator.setObservations(double[]), then the return value is a single time-series of local AIS values corresponding to these samples (with the first (k-1)*tau + 1 values set to 0 since AIS is undefined there).

        Otherwise where disjoint time-series observations were supplied using several calls such as ActiveInfoStorageCalculator.addObservations(double[]) then the local values for each disjoint observation set will be appended here to create a single "time-series" return array (without any (k-1)*tau + 1 leading 0 values).

        Specified by:
        computeLocalOfPreviousObservations in interface ActiveInfoStorageCalculator
        Returns:
        the "time-series" of local AIS values.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations

        public double[] computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations(double[] newObservations)
                                               throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from interface: ActiveInfoStorageCalculator
        Compute the local AIS values for each of the supplied samples in newObservations.

        PDFs are computed using all of the previously supplied observations, but not those in newObservations (unless they were some of the previously supplied samples).

        Specified by:
        computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations in interface ActiveInfoStorageCalculator
        Parameters:
        newObservations - time-series for which to compute local AIS values
        Returns:
        time-series of local AIS values corresponding to newObservations (the first (k-1)*tau + 1 values are set to 0 since AIS is undefined there)
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - for an invalid input array, e.g. of length less than k+1

      • computeSignificance

        public EmpiricalMeasurementDistribution computeSignificance(int numPermutationsToCheck)
                                                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from interface: EmpiricalNullDistributionComputer
        Generate an empirical (bootstrapped) distribution of what the given measure would look like, under a null hypothesis that the source values of our samples had no relation to the destination value (possibly in the context of a conditional value).

        See Section II.E "Statistical significance testing" of the JIDT paper below for a description of how this is done for MI, conditional MI and TE.

        Note that if several disjoint time-series have been added as observations using addObservations methods etc., then these separate "trials" will be mixed up in the generation of surrogates here.

        References:

        • J.T. Lizier, "JIDT: An information-theoretic toolkit for studying the dynamics of complex systems", 2014.
        Specified by:
        computeSignificance in interface EmpiricalNullDistributionComputer
        Parameters:
        numPermutationsToCheck - number of surrogate samples to bootstrap to generate the distribution.
        Returns:
        the empirical distribution of measure scores under this null hypothesis.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception
        See Also:
        "J.T. Lizier, 'JIDT: An information-theoretic toolkit for studying the dynamics of complex systems', 2014."

      • computeSignificance

        public EmpiricalMeasurementDistribution computeSignificance(int[][] newOrderings)
                                                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from interface: EmpiricalNullDistributionComputer
        Generate an empirical (bootstrapped) distribution of what the given measure would look like, under a null hypothesis that the source values of our samples had no relation to the destination value (possibly in the context of a conditional value).

        See Section II.E "Statistical significance testing" of the JIDT paper below for a description of how this is done MI, conditional MI and TE.

        Note that if several disjoint time-series have been added as observations using addObservations methods etc., then these separate "trials" will be mixed up in the generation of surrogates here.

        This method (in contrast to EmpiricalNullDistributionComputer.computeSignificance(int)) allows the user to specify how to construct the surrogates, such that repeatable results may be obtained.

        References:

        • J.T. Lizier, "JIDT: An information-theoretic toolkit for studying the dynamics of complex systems", 2014.
        Specified by:
        computeSignificance in interface EmpiricalNullDistributionComputer
        Parameters:
        newOrderings - a specification of how to shuffle the next values to create the surrogates to generate the distribution with. The first index is the permutation number (i.e. newOrderings.length is the number of surrogate samples we use to bootstrap to generate the distribution here.) Each array newOrderings[i] should be an array of length N (where would be the value returned by a call to getNumObservations() for the given measure) containing a permutation of the values in 0..(N-1).
        Returns:
        the empirical distribution of measure scores under this null hypothesis.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - where e.g. the newOrderings don't supply arrays of the correct length matching the number of observations that we have.
        See Also:
        "J.T. Lizier, 'JIDT: An information-theoretic toolkit for studying the dynamics of complex systems', 2014."

      • getNumObservations

        public int getNumObservations()
                       throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from interface: InfoMeasureCalculatorContinuous
        Get the number of samples to be used for the PDFs here which have been supplied by calls to "setObservations", "addObservations" etc.

        Note that the number of samples may not be equal to the length of time-series supplied (e.g. for transfer entropy, where we need to accumulate a number of samples for the past history of the destination).

        Specified by:
        getNumObservations in interface InfoMeasureCalculatorContinuous
        Returns:
        the number of samples to be used for the PDFs
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception
